articles.headline: Families Bear Brunt of Deployment Strains
articles.snippet: Since 2001, more than a million families of service members have borne the brunt of the psychological and emotional strain of their deployment.
articles.abstract: Since 2001, more than a million families of service members have borne the brunt of the psychological and emotional strain of their deployment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUTOMA, Wis. — Life changed for Shawn Eisch with a phone call last January. His youngest brother, Brian, a soldier and single father, had just received orders to deploy from Fort Drum, N.Y., to Afghanistan and was mulling who might take his two boys for a year. Shawn volunteered.
articles.byline: By James Dao and Catrin Einhorn

articles.headline: Major Banks Need Midsize Ones
articles.snippet: Just as baseball teams need a farm system to provide replacements for players who age, a banking system needs a second tier of institutions that can step in and become major league.
articles.abstract: Just as baseball teams need a farm system to provide replacements for players who age, a banking system needs a second tier of institutions that can step in and become major league.
articles.lead_paragraph: If big banks start failing again, what will replace them?

articles.headline: For Sushi Chain, Conveyor Belts Carry Profit
articles.snippet: The Kura “revolving sushi” chain has succeeded where many of Japan’s celebrated eateries fall short: turning a profit in a punishing economy.
articles.abstract: The Kura “revolving sushi” chain has succeeded where many of Japan’s celebrated eateries fall short: turning a profit in a punishing economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYAMA, Japan  The Kura “revolving sushi” restaurant chain has no Michelin stars, but it has succeeded where many of Japan’s more celebrated eateries fall short: turning a profit in a punishing economy.

articles.headline: Twins’ Facebook Fight Rages On
articles.snippet: The Winklevoss twins have considered dropping their effort to unwind a settlement in their suit against Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook. They decided, though, to keep fighting.
articles.abstract: The Winklevoss twins have considered dropping their effort to unwind a settlement in their suit against Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook. They decided, though, to keep fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  Some people go to court hoping to win millions of dollars. Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss have already won tens of millions. But six years into a legal feud with Facebook, they want to give it back  for a chance to get more.

articles.headline: Shaping a Network With Oprah’s View
articles.snippet: Oprah Winfrey and Discovery Communications are betting that media will become more personalized — beginning with a channel built around one of the biggest personalities on TV.
articles.abstract: Oprah Winfrey and Discovery Communications are betting that media will become more personalized — beginning with a channel built around one of the biggest personalities on TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades cable channels have been built around specific interests like news, sports or classic movies. Beginning this weekend, there will be something altogether different: a cable channel shaped around a person, Oprah Winfrey.

articles.headline: Tricky Call for New Governors: Price of Inaugurals
articles.snippet: After their election night victory speeches, 26 new governors have had to decide how big a party to throw themselves.
articles.abstract: After their election night victory speeches, 26 new governors have had to decide how big a party to throw themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — To warm up the Florida crowds for his inauguration as governor, Rick Scott has been flying around the state this week on a seven-city “appreciation” tour. For the main event on Tuesday, he will lead a parade featuring 26 marching bands, followed by a black-tie dinner for 2,100 people, with oysters Rockefeller and fried calamari served in mini-martini glasses. “Real classy,” said Christy Noftz, who is overseeing the catering.

articles.headline: Academic Economists to Consider Ethics Code
articles.snippet: The discussion comes amid new scrutiny of economists, particularly those active in policy debates in Washington and Wall Street while serving on corporate boards.
articles.abstract: The discussion comes amid new scrutiny of economists, particularly those active in policy debates in Washington and Wall Street while serving on corporate boards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the Stanford business professor Darrell Duffie co-wrote a book on how to overhaul Wall Street regulations, he did not mention that he sits on the board of Moody’s, the credit rating agency.

articles.headline: CVS Caremark Agrees To Buy a Medicare D Unit
articles.snippet: The company is continuing to expand even as it fights criticism that it engages in anticompetitive practices.
articles.abstract: The company is continuing to expand even as it fights criticism that it engages in anticompetitive practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: CVS Caremark on Friday agreed to buy a Medicare business for $1.25 billion, an acquisition that may open the nation’s largest pharmacy health care provider to further criticism about anticompetitive practices.

articles.headline: Some Investors Flourish Despite Economic Tumult
articles.snippet: In 2010, unemployment lingered in America and some European economies tottered, but investing in gold, industrials and many technology stocks turned out well.
articles.abstract: In 2010, unemployment lingered in America and some European economies tottered, but investing in gold, industrials and many technology stocks turned out well.
articles.lead_paragraph: An economy stuck in neutral. Unemployment that refused to go down. And a near financial disaster in Europe.
